DOC.brief_summary: An Allis clamp causes less pain and bleeding than a single tooth tenaculum when used for mobilization of the cervix during common gynecologic office procedures. The primary object is to determine the presence of a difference in pain perception between the two instruments. The secondary objective is to evaluate the differences in the frequency of bleeding, that requires treatment, after removal of the instrument and the need to use an alternative instruments.
DOC.brief_title: A Comparison of Two Instruments for Stabilization of the Cervix During Office Procedures
DOC.criteria: Female Between 18 and 89 years of age Undergoing an IUD placement IUD placement within the last 6 months Active cervical or pelvic infection pregnant Patient taking coagulation medications
